result.execSummary:
The defendant Zachary S Friedlander was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
--Statutory costs of $268

--$45 subpoena fees

--No possession of controlled substances without a valid prescription

--No possession of any hypodermic needle unless medically necessary as confirmed by a physician

--No contact with Lindsey Bickle

--No contact with any known drug offender except for treatment purposes as deemed appropriate per agent

--Any other assessment, treatment or counseling per Agent

--Random drug and/or alcohol screening
 (at least 1x per month upon release from prison)

Arresting Agency: JCSD

If probation, parole or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of the victim(s) and government entities for the balance due.
--AODA & follow through with recommended treatment per Agent
--Obtain/maintain employment and/or education program per Agent

timeConds.notes:
-- 8 months Jail, to begin today.

Court further authorizes Huber release and work release on his conditional jail term

No DNA Sample Ordered

Defendant is required to report for commencement and service of jail sentence with absolute sobriety and without non-prescribed controlled substances in his/her system.  Non-compliance will result in loss of Huber/work-release privileges without further process.

Case called at 11:07am [ma]
Defendant Zachary S Friedlander in court with Attorney Jordan Lippert.  Susan Victoria Happ appears for the State of Wisconsin.
Atty. Lippert indicates that he is making a special appearance on behalf of Mr. Friedlander; as been unable to receive response from SPD as to representation of Mr. Friedlander
Upon inquiry of the Court, Atty. Lippert indicates that he is willing to represent Mr. Friedlander
The Court appoints Atty. Lippert at county expense

On Jefferson County Sheriff's Dept. 11/23/16 Letter:
--Counsel verify receipt of Letter
The Court takes judicial notice of JOC and the sentence ordered by the Court

Brian Dykstra--Corrections Field Supervisor present in the Courtroom gallery
--the Court questions Mr. Dystra

The Court determines that the Sheriffs Dept has not determined whether Mr. Friedlander is free to use work release/Huber privileges

The Court and Counsel review Wis. Stat. 302.43 and State v. Fearing

The Court finds that Defendant has served 165 days of the 8 month sentence 
The Court questions Deputy Kanters who is present in the Courtroom gallery

Srgt. Handrow appears via telephone, the Court questions Srgt. Handrow
Srgt. Handrow calculates 8 months of conditional jail time to be 240 days 

Deputy Owen appears via telephone
--the Court questions Deputy Owen
--Atty Lippert questions Deputy Owen 
--DA Happ questions Deputy Owen

The Court finds that Defendant was released from custody at OCI on 9/27/16 and has NOT been in custody at JCJ since that time.
The Court directs the Counsel to review State v. Demars, Nyborg and Rohl re: Detainers
The Court determines that the 65 days that Defendant has not been in custody at either OCI or JCJ, he has not been generating credit due to a detainer being in place.
Atty Lippert recites State v. Riscke and State v. Dentici

The Court finds that Mr. Friedlander was present in court during sentencing

Mr. Zachary Friedlander--sworn and testifies
--questioning by Atty. Lippert
--questioning by the Court
--questioning by DA Happ

Arguments given by Atty. Lippert 
The Court finds that Mr. Friedlander is not entitiled to any sentence credit from his release from OCI to today.
The Court remands Mr. Friedlander to the custody to serve the remainder of his senence which is: 75 days of conditional jail.
recess: 12:37pm
Hearing on December 1, 2016 at 11:00 am.
from JCSD requesting clarification of sentence
Criminal Case Settlement

records.addlTxt:
Case called at 10:45 am [Clerk SH]
Defendant Zachary S Friedlander in court, in-custody, with Attorney Jordan Lippert. DA Susan Victoria Happ appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
DA Happ confirms victim rights compliance; Court so finds

Constitutional rights given; plea of "No Contest" entered on Count #1; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; Court finds the plea has been entered freely, voluntarily, intelligently and accepts the plea, finds Defendant guilty, and orders JOC entered.
On Motion of the State, the Court reads-in and dismisses Count #2

On Count #1, the Court withholds sentence, places Defendant on Probation for 3 years to begin today with 8 months Jail, to begin today.

Court further orders all other conditions of probation as outlined on the criminal case settlement which include: 
--AODA & follow through with recommended treatment per Agent
--Any other assessment, treatment or counseling per Agent
--Random drug and/or alcohol screening (at least 1x per month upon release from prison)
--Obtain/maintain employment and/or education program per Agent
--No possession of controlled substances without a valid prescription
--No possession of any hypodermic needle unless medically necessary as confirmed by a physician
--No contact with Lindsey Bickle
--No contact with any known drug offender except for treatment purposes as deemed appropriate per agent
--Statutory costs of $268
--DNA Surcharge of $250
No DNA Sample ordered

Court additionally orders:
$45 subpoena fees
Court finds that the Defendant is eligible for Challenge Incaceration and Substance Abuse Programming
Court further authorizes Huber release and work release on his conditional jail term

Days credit for time already served: 0 days
Felony Firearm/Voting Prohibitions Warnings Form Given
Court orders Atty Lippert to confer with Mr. Friedlander regarding his post conviction rights
Recess: 11:22 am

Defendant Zachary S Friedlander in court, in custody with Attorney Jordan Lippert.  ADA Monica J. Hall appears for the State of Wisconsin.

Case called at 2:04pm [mo]
Defendant Zachary S Friedlander appears via video conferencing, from Dodge Corr. Inst., in custody.    ADA Jeffrey Shock appears for the State of Wisconsin. 
   
The Court finds that the video conferencing system is sight and sound sufficient. 
The Court verifies Mr. Friedlander's date of birth and address on the Criminal Complaint. 
Service of Complaint admitted, reading waived, the charge and maximum penalties are recited
Right to counsel given; constructive waiver of counsel warnings given
--Mr. Friedlander indicates that he wishes to have counsel

The Court adjourns this hearing to allow Mr. Friedlander time to seek counsel.
The State does not request bond at this time. 
recess: 2:13pm

NEXT:  Adjourned Initial Appearance on 2/16/16 at 2:00pm

Case called at 3:01pm [mo]
Defendant Zachary S Friedlander not in court.   DA Susan Happ appears for the State of Wisconsin.
 
The Court discloses, under SCR 60.04 that in the Court's former capacity as Jefferson County District Attorney, attorneys that DA Wambach supervised did prosecute Mr. Friedlander. The Court does not feel that any disqualification or recusal is needed.

DA Happ indicates that Mr. Friedlander is currently in custody at Oshkosh CI
The Court adjourns for personal service.
The Court directs the next hearing to be by video if possible.
